CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 15, 1960, pg. 1 reads: "Over 6,000 Persons Await Senator Kennedy in Hill - More than 6,000 persons crowded the intersection at Centre Ave. and Devilliers St. on Monday night to hear Democratic presidential candidate Senator John F. Kennedy. Veteran campaigners said that it was the largest crowd to turn out for a presidential candidate since the days of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt...Senator Kennedy charged that under the GOP regime in Washington, Negroes had been deprived of housing, job, wage and educational opportunities.  Also, that the Eisenhower administration "hasn't appointed a Negro judge in its eight years," and further declared that persons with Federal contracts should be required to practice equal rights in giving out jobs. - Harris Photo."
TitMainTitle: Crowd on roof and in front of market with sign reading: "Welcome Senator John F. Kennedy here October 10," during Kennedy - Johnson presidential campaign, Hill District
